_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Delphos Cooperative Association- Delphos Branch

Prepared By: Steve Hoesli



1. The Facility Policy

Our employees will do what is possible with their training to stop the release, but will not be emergency responders. The Delphos fire department will be the emergency responders and the Local Emergency Planning Committee will be used for major evacuations.



2. Facility Information

The NH3 facility is located directly west of the city limits. Delphos receives storage and distributes Anhydrous Ammonia to farmers as agricultural nutrient.



3. The Worst Case and Alternate Release Scenario

Worst case scenario would release 103,069 pounds in a 10 minute period or 10,306 pounds per minute with a 1.02 mile to end point. Alternate release could involve a transfer hose rupture this would result in a release of 7,127 pounds in a 2 minute period with a 0.46 mile to end point.



4. Accidental Release Prevention

The Delphos Cooperative Association recognizes all safety regulations and procedures required by State and Federal Agencies

and has annual training for the employees. The most common accidental release would be the overfilling of nurse trailers: An example would be a nurse trailer filled to 90% on a cool morning, as the air temperature rises, the product expands and causes the pressure relief valve to let product escape. Delphos Cooperative Association Policy is not to fill above 85%.



5. Five Year Accident History

There has not been a reportable accident in the last five years.



6. Emergency Response Program

The Delphos Cooperative Association has an Emergency Action Plan and a Safety Director. All areas have worked with the County, City and Insurance Company Loss Control Department for the development of these plans.



7. Planned Safety Changes

The Company Safety Director, Operations Manager tour the Branch once per month All areas are toured once a quarter. Changes are made on an as needed basis as new regulations or concerns arise.
